name: French Lavender
climate: French Lavender thrives best in climates with warm, dry summers and mild winters.
This plant is well-suited for Mediterranean climates that rarely experience frost.
Avoid regions with high humidity or harsh, cold winters as these can harm the plant.
It prefers a stable temperature range, avoiding extreme heat or freezing points.
sunlight: French Lavender requires full sun exposure, ideally around 6 to 8 hours daily.
Inadequate sunlight may affect blooming, so ensure it is grown in bright conditions.
Placing it in a sunny location helps promote healthy growth and vibrant flowers.
Partial shade can be tolerated, but optimal flowering occurs with maximum sunlight.
watering: Allow the soil to dry between waterings to prevent root rot, watering sparingly.
Overwatering is a common mistake; French Lavender prefers drier conditions.
It's important to maintain moderate soil moisture, reducing water during dormancy.
In drought conditions, occasional deep watering helps sustain its growth efficiently.
soil: French Lavender thrives in well-draining soils, preventing excess moisture retention.
A sandy or gritty soil mixture can help ensure proper drainage for lavender plants.
Soil should be neutral to slightly alkaline; avoid overly acidic conditions for optimal growth.
Poor soil quality can be enhanced with organic matter to support the plant's health.
extra_care_tip: Prune French Lavender regularly to maintain shape and promote bushier growth.
Mulching with inorganic material helps retain soil dryness and repels weeds.
